messageBody:
James Cheesman Fri, 30 Apr 2004 09:09:43 +0200
> I stand by my comment on the long term solution being a separation
> of GUI and other code.

You're wrong: separation (e.g. MVC) is at best part of the solution.
It is better to *actually* test, i.e. by putting real UI events on the
queue, a poorly-structured UI (which one can refactor later) than to
speculatively test a perfectly-designed one; ceteris paribus, it is
better to release code that is imperfectly designed but completely
tested than code that is perfectly designed but incompletely tested.

MVC is good design, bringing a host of benefits, e.g. reusability.
But to assert (as you seem to, and as the currently orthodox view
(e.g. "Humble Dialog Box") does) that if one MVCs one's UI, and then
only tests the model and control, one has sufficiently tested one's
UI, was false then and is false now. Just as there is no substitute
for actually testing the model and control, there is no substitute for
actually testing the view itself, with actual UI events. Anything less
is merely speculative, at best second-best.

As I have previously stated (e.g.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/10457

) it was at one time legitimate to say "I can't xUnit my UI, so I will
try to do the best I can," i.e. create a thin UI well-separated from
its model and control. But it was *never* legitimate to make a virtue
of necessity, to say (as you do) that "separation is the solution."
Now that you *can* drive your UIs from JUnit, and therefore you can
*fully* test your UIs, your claim is illegitimate, and moreover
encourages the "anti-test-infection."
